questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents after being trapped under a motorcycle for several hours. He has severe thigh pain and dark-colored urine. Examination shows swollen, tender thighs. Labs: sodium 134 mEq/L, potassium 6.2 mEq/L, urea 95 mg/dL, creatinine 5.8 mg/dL, calcium 7.9 mg/dL, phosphate 6.8 mg/dL. Urine dipstick is positive for blood, but no RBCs are seen on microscopy. Which of the following investigations is most likely to confirm the diagnosis? (Ref values: s. creatinine: 0.6-1.4 mg/dl; S. urea: 17 - 43 mg/dL; s. sodium: 135-145 mEq/L; S. potassium: 3.5-5 mEq/L; S. calcium: 8.8 - 10 mg/dl; S. phosphate: 3.0-4.5 mg/dL)
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Serum creatine kinase(CK) is an enzyme released from damaged skeletal muscle
  • In rhabdomyolysis, muscle breakdown leads to massive elevation of CK (often >5,000 IU/L; sometimes >100,000 IU/L). It is the most sensitive and specific marker for diagnosing rhabdomyolysis.

Rhabdomyolysis:

Rhabdomyolysis is the breakdown of skeletal muscle fibres, resulting in the release of myoglobin, electrolytes, and enzymes (like CK) into the bloodstream.

Causes of rhabdomyolysis are:

  • Traumatic crush injuries
  • Muscle ischemia during vascular or orthopaedic surgery
  • Compression during coma or immobilisation
  • Prolonged seizure activity
  • Excessive exercise
  • Heat stroke
  • Malignant hyperthermia
  • Infections
  • Metabolic disorders (e.g., hypophosphatemia, severe hypothyroidism)
  • Myopathies (drug-induced, metabolic, or inflammatory).

Lab Findings:

Very high (>5000 IU/L) Serum CK, Hyperkalemia, Hyperphosphatemia, Hypocalcemia initially, increased Creatinine & urea, and Myoglobinuria

Treatment:

Treatment is with hydration (normal saline) and alkalinisation of urine with sodium bicarbonate infusion.

Explanation of Other Options:

Renal ultrasound(Option B): This patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) due to rhabdomyolysis, not obstruction. Renal ultrasound may show enlarged kidneys in AKI, but it is not diagnostic for rhabdomyolysis.

Serum myoglobin(Option C): Myoglobin is a muscle protein released into the blood after muscle injury. Although it directly reflects muscle breakdown, myoglobin levels fall quickly after injury and can be missed by the time of presentation. CK is more reliable, as it remains elevated for a longer period and is more accessible.

ECG(Option D): ECG detects electrolyte complications of rhabdomyolysis, not the cause. It is critical for emergency management, but not for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male has taken a drug overdose of multiple drugs. Which one of the following can be effectively removed by haemodialysis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lithium's low molecular weight, water solubility, and low volume of distribution make it highly amenable to removal by hemodialysis, which rapidly clears the drug from the bloodstream, especially in cases of acute toxicity or renal impairment where urinary excretion is compromised.

Indications for Hemodialysis in Lithium Toxicity:

  • Serum lithium level > 6.0 mEq/L: Irrespective of symptoms or kidney function.
  • Serum lithium level > 4.0 mEq/L in a patient on chronic lithium therapy: Due to the risk of intracellular accumulation and prolonged toxicity.
  • Serum lithium level between 2.5- 4.0 mEq/L With any of the following:
    • Severe neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures, confusion, coma)
    • Renal failure
    • Hemodynamic instability
  • Serum lithium level < 2.5 mEq/L with underlying end-stage kidney disease (ESKD): As lithium clearance is significantly impaired.
  • Rising or persistent lithium levels after admission:
    • Serum lithium levels increase after initial decline
    • Lithium levels fail to drop below 1.0 mEq/L within 30 hours

List of dialysable drugs: Mnemonic 'ldquo;I STUMBLE'

Dialysis should be considered in cases of severe poisoning due to:

  • I- INH, Isopropyl alcohol
  • S- Salicylates
  • T- Theophylline, Tenormin
  • U- Uremia
  • M- Methanol
  • B- Barbiturates
  • L- Lithium
  • E- Ethylene glycol
  • D- Dabigatran, Depakote

Explanation of Other Options:

Amiodarone (Option A) is highly lipophilic, with a large volume of distribution and high protein binding, making it poorly dialyzable.

Digoxin (Option B) has a large volume of distribution (binds to tissues like myocardium) and moderate protein-binding, which implies that it is a poor candidate for dialysis.

Phenytoin (Option C) has high protein binding and a large volume of distribution, making it poorly dialysable.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with generalised weakness and bilateral leg swelling. He recently returned from a trip to India, during which he had an episode of bloody diarrhoea about three weeks ago. He now reports reduced urine output. Blood tests show: Hb 8 g/dL, WBC: 14,000/ &ml;L, Neutrophils: 9000/ &ml;L, Platelets: 20,000/&ml;L, PT 13s, APTT 33s, Fibrinogen 4 g/dL, sodium 136 mmol/ L, potassium 6.1 mmol/L, urea 420 mg/dl, creatinine 7.8 mg/dl, albumin 3 g/dL. Urine dipstick: blood ++, protein +. What is the next best investigation to confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of renal failure, anaemia, and thrombocytopenia following a diarrheal illness is suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), a thrombotic microangiopathy. The most common cause is Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (especially O157:H7). Stool culture helps identify the causative organism and confirm the diagnosis.

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome:

  • Thrombotic microangiopathy is characterised by the triad of acute renal failure, Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia, and thrombocytopenia.
  • Types of HUS:
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Shiga toxin damages endothelial cells, especially in the renal glomeruli.
    • Leads to microthrombi formation → RBC fragmentation (schistocytes) → anaemia, low platelets, and AKI.
  • Lab findings:
    • ↓ Hb, ↓ Platelets, ↑ WBC, peripheral smear showing Schistocytes, elevated LDH, decreased Haptoglobin, Hematuria, proteinuria, stool culture showing EHEC (E. coli O157:H7) or Shigella, ↑ Urea, ↑ Creatinine
  • Management:
    • Supportive Care
    • Dialysis if indicated
    • Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) for symptomatic anaemia
    • Avoid Antibiotics & Anti-Motility Drugs (in typical HUS) as antibiotics increase toxin, and anti-motility can cause an increase in toxin exposure time
    • Plasma Exchange / Plasmapheresis is used in atypical HUS
    • Eculizumab blocks the C5 complement protein and is indicated in atypical HUS

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with new-onset ankle swelling. Two weeks earlier, he was treated with painkillers for pleuritic chest pain following a chest infection. On examination, his blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg. Urinalysis shows +++ proteinuria with no hematuria. Serum creatinine is 1.4 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The most likely diagnosis is NSAID-induced membranous nephropathy, a nephrotic syndrome.

Membranous Nephropathy:

Membranous nephropathy is a glomerular disease characterized by immune complex deposition on the subepithelial side of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), leading to thickened capillary walls and nephrotic syndrome.

Etiology:

Primary (Idiopathic) MN - 75%

  • Autoantibodies against PLA2R (Phospholipase A2 Receptor) or THSD7A on podocytes
  • Seen in middle-aged adults

Secondary MN - 25%("MALES" Mnemonic):

  • Malignancy (solid tumors- lung, colon, breast)
  • Autoimmune (SLE - class V)
  • Lupus (SLE) - a common cause in younger women
  • Exposure (NSAIDs, gold, penicillamine)
  • Secondary infections (HBV, HCV, syphilis)

Clinical Features:

  • Nephrotic syndrome:
    • Massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day)
    • Hypoalbuminemia
    • Edema (esp. periorbital, pedal)
    • Hyperlipidemia
    • Lipiduria (fatty casts/"Maltese crosses")
  • No hematuria or minimal

Investigations:

  • Urinalysis: +++ proteinuria, Presence of oval fat bodies (lipiduria)
  • Serum Albumin: Markedly decreased (↓ due to protein loss in urine)
  • Lipid Profile: Increased cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Serum Creatinine / BUN: Usually normal or mildly elevated. Depends on disease duration and severity
  • Anti-PLA2R Antibodies: Positive in most cases of primary (idiopathic) membranous nephropathy. Useful to distinguish from secondary causes
  • Renal Biopsy (Gold Standard for Diagnosis):
    • Light Microscopy (LM): Thickened glomerular basement membrane (GBM)
    • Immunofluorescence (IF): Granular deposits of IgG and C3 along GBM
    • Electron Microscopy (EM): Subepithelial immune deposits forming a classic "spike and dome" appearance

Management:

General Measures:

  • Salt restriction, diuretics for edema
  • ACE inhibitors/ARBs to reduce proteinuria
  • Statins for hyperlipidemia
  • Anticoagulation if thrombotic risk is high (e.g., albumin <2.0 g/dL)

Specific:

  • Primary MN:
    • Low-risk: Conservative, monitor
    • High-risk (persistent proteinuria >4 g/day, ↓GFR): Immunosuppressants (e.g., rituximab, steroids + cyclophosphamide)
  • Secondary MN:
    • Treat the underlying cause (e.g., stop NSAIDs, treat HBV, manage cancer)

Explanation of Other Options:

Renal Amyloidosis(Option A): Usually associated with chronic inflammatory diseases (e.g., RA, TB), Common in older age. Rare in this setting and not linked to recent NSAID use.

Interstitial Nephritis(Option B): NSAIDs can cause it, but it usually presents with AKI, has eosinophiluria, fever, rash, and mild proteinuria, but not nephrotic-range proteinuria

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (Option D): Can cause nephrotic syndrome, more common in African ancestry, HIV, obesity, or heroin use. Would expect more severe renal dysfunction or hypertension

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents with chest pain and pulmonary oedema. He is diagnosed with acute coronary syndrome and has hypotension (BP 85/60 mmHg) on admission. He also has Streptococcal pneumonia and was started on Augmentin (amoxicillin + clavulanic acid). His blood tests on admission show a creatinine of 1.45 mg/dl rising to 1.90 mg/dl, 2.50 mg/dl the day after, and then returns to 1.3 mg/dL by day 5. Urine dipstick shows 1+ proteinuria and muddy brown granular casts. What is the most likely cause of renal failure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient developed acute kidney injury following hypotension due to acute coronary syndrome, with muddy brown granular casts indicating acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

Acute tubular necrosis (ATN):

  • Involves the death of tubular cells that form the tubule that transports urine to the ureters while reabsorbing 99% of the water.
  • Tubular cells continually replace themselves, and if the cause of ATN is removed, then recovery is likely.

Causes of ATN:

  • Sepsis
  • Ischemia
  • Toxins:
    1. Endogenous: Hemolysis, rhabdomyolysis, myeloma, intratubular crystals
    2. Exogenous: Iodinated contrast, aminoglycosides, cisplatin, amphotericin B, PPIs, NSAIDs

Explanation of Other Options:

Urinary tract infection (Option A): In a UTI, there is pyuria on urinalysis, along with typical symptoms such as fever and possibly WBC casts.

Interstitial nephritis due to Augmentin (Option C): Present with fever, rash, and eosinophilia. Urine in interstitial nephritis will also show hyaline casts (but not muddy), WBC casts, or WBCs.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option D): Usually occurs 1-3 weeks after a streptococcal infection (pharyngitis or impetigo). Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis will lead to the presence of RBCs or RBC casts and not hyaline casts.

choices.text: IgG deposition in the basement membrane

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with chest pain and is thrombolysed for an acute myocardial infarction. His blood pressure was 85/40 for several hours on admission. Two days later, his blood tests showed a urea of 140 mg/dl and creatinine of 3 mg/dl (Urea and Electrolytes were normal on admission). What would a renal biopsy show?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient had prolonged hypotension following an acute MI, leading to ischemic acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
  • The S3 segment of the proximal tubule in the outer medulla is most vulnerable to hypoxia, resulting in necrosis or loss of tubular epithelial cells seen on biopsy.

Acute Tubular Necrosis:

  • ATN is a form of intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI) caused by damage to renal tubular epithelial cells, leading to acute renal dysfunction.

Types:

  • Ischemic ATN - due to prolonged hypotension or hypoperfusion
    • g., Shock, sepsis, severe dehydration, surgery
  • Nephrotoxic ATN- due to direct tubular toxin injury
    • g., Drugs: Aminoglycosides, Amphotericin B, Cisplatin
    • Contrast-induced nephropathy
    • Myoglobin (rhabdomyolysis), haemoglobin (hemolysis), uric acid (TLS)

Lab Findings:

  • ↑ Creatinine & urea
  • Muddy brown granular casts in urine (key diagnostic feature)
  • Fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa) > 2%
  • Urine sodium > 40 mEq/L
  • Urine osmolality < 350 mOsm/kg

Treatment:

  • Supportive care
    • Maintain BP, hydration
    • Stop nephrotoxic agents
  • Dialysis if:
    • Severe uremia, hyperkalemia, fluid overload, metabolic acidosis
  • Recovery is expected in 1-3 weeks if the basement membrane is intact.

Explanation of Other Options:

Positive antibody to fibrinogen (Option A): Suggests crescentic glomerulonephritis, not ischemic ATN.

Thickened capillary loops (Option B): Suggests membranous nephropathy, not ATN.

IgG deposition in the basement membrane (Option D): Seen in membranous GN or post-infectious GN, not ATN..

questions.text: A 49-year-old man with a history of alcohol abuse was admitted for treatment of alcoholic hepatitis. He has jaundice, tense ascites, severe leg oedema, and mild to moderate encephalopathy. His blood tests revealed: urea 192 mg/dl, creatinine 5 mg/dl, ALT 140 (5-35) U/l, AST 180 (A-31) U/l, ALP 360 (20-120) U/l, Bilirubin total 2.2 mg/dl, Albumin 3 g/dl. Which of the following should he be treated with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient with alcoholic hepatitis, jaundice, ascites, encephalopathy, and rising urea/creatinine is likely developing hepatorenal syndrome (HRS). Terlipressin, a vasopressin analogue, is the first-line treatment for HRS as it improves renal perfusion.

Hepatorenal Syndrome (HRS):

  • Functional renal failure occurs in patients with advanced liver disease (usually cirrhosis or fulminant hepatic failure), due to severe renal vasoconstriction, without structural kidney damage.

Types of HRS:

Diagnostic Criteria (based on ICA 2015/2019):

  • Cirrhosis with ascites
  • Acute kidney injury (AKI) as per KDIGO criteria (↑ serum creatinine ≥0.3 mg/dL in 48 hrs or ≥50% in <7 days)
  • No improvement in kidney function after 2 days of diuretic withdrawal and volume expansion with albumin
  • No shock, no nephrotoxins
  • No parenchymal kidney disease (i.e., no significant proteinuria, hematuria, or abnormal renal ultrasound)

Pathophysiology:

  • Splanchnic vasodilation → ↓ effective arterial blood volume
  • Compensatory renal vasoconstriction → ↓ GFR
  • RAAS, sympathetic nervous system, and vasopressin system are activated → worsens renal hypoperfusion

Treatment :

  • Volume replacement
  • Stopping diuretics
  • Albumin + vasopressors (Terlipressin/ Nor epinephrine/ vasopressin/ Octreotide with midodrine) is the approved treatment.
  • Liver transplantation is the definitive management.

Explanation of Other Options:

Normal saline (Option A): can worsen ascites, is not effective in HRS

ACE inhibitor (Option C): ACE inhibitor is contraindicated in HRS as it decreases GFR further

Renal transplant (Option D) is not suitable unless liver disease is treated or a combined liver-kidney transplant is planned; not an acute treatment

questions.text: A 28-year-old man was found to have acute renal failure. Which of the following is an indication for urgent dialysis in renal failure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a patient with acute renal failure, the presence of pericardial effusion indicates uremic pericarditis, which is an absolute indication for urgent dialysis.

Indications for Dialysis:

  • Dialysis indications are divided into:
    • Emergent (life-threatening without dialysis)
    • Non-emergent (chronic management, e.g., ESRD)
  • Emergent Indications ("AEIOU" Mnemonic):
    • A - Acidosis: Severe metabolic acidosis unresponsive to medical therapy
    • E - Electrolyte imbalance: Especially hyperkalemia (e.g., K+ > 6.5 mmol/L with ECG changes or refractory)
    • I - Ingestion: Toxic alcohols, salicylates, lithium, etc.
    • O - Overload: Fluid overload leading to pulmonary edema/heart failure
    • U - Uremia: Complications like encephalopathy or pericarditis
  • Non-Emergent Indication:
    • End-stage renal disease (ESRD): Dialysis is needed for long-term survival when renal function is irreversibly lost

Explanation of Other Options:

Chest pain (Option A): Unless the chest pain is specifically due to uremic pericarditis (confirmed by effusion or friction rub), it's not an absolute indication for dialysis.

Potassium of 5 mmol/l (Option B): Dialysis is indicated when potassium is more than 6.5 mmol/l

Glomerulonephritis (Option C) is a cause of renal failure, not an immediate indication for dialysis on its own.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7121551/

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has presented with palpitations and dizziness. His heart rate was 40 beats per minute. Upon investigation, he has the following results: sodium 132 mmol/L, potassium 7.6mmol/L, urea 122 mg/dl, creatinine 4.7 mg/dl. What should be the initial management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has symptomatic hyperkalemia (K+7.6 mmol/L) with bradycardia, indicating a cardiac conduction risk, which is a medical emergency.
  • The initial management is IV calcium gluconate to stabilize the cardiac membrane, followed by measures like insulin-dextrose or dialysis to reduce serum potassium.

Immediate Cardiac Protection:D

IV Calcium Gluconate stabilizes cardiac membranes, raises the action potential threshold. First-line to prevent arrhythmias

Rapid Redistribution of K+ into Cells:

  • Insulin + Dextrose: Shifts K+intracellularly. Used after cardiac stabilization
  • β2-Agonists (e.g., Albuterol): Promote cellular K+ uptake. Use with caution in cardiac patients
  • IV Bicarbonate: Useful in acidosis-related hyperkalemia

Removal of Potassium from the Body:

  • Cation Exchange Resins (e.g., SPS): Promote GI K+excretion
  • New Binders (Patiromer, ZS-9): Safer alternatives to SPS
  • Diuretics (Loop/Thiazide): Effective if the kidneys are functioning. Not suitable for hypovolemia or renal failure
  • Hemodialysis: Most effective method. Indicated in severe or refractory hyperkalemia, AKI, or CKD. Peritoneal dialysis is less effective

questions.text: In a patient with renal failure, use of which of the following medications would suggest a possible diagnosis of retroperitoneal fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Methysergide causes retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Causes of Retroperitoneal Fibrosis:

  • Benign:
    • Idiopathic (Ormond's disease)
    • Chronic inflammation
    • Extravasation of urine
    • Retroperitoneal irritation by leakage of blood or intestinal content
    • Aortic aneurysm (inflammatory type)
    • Trauma
  • Malignant:
    • Lymphoma
    • Carcinoid tumor
    • Secondary deposits(especially from carcinoma of stomach, colon, breast, and prostate)
  • Drugs associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis include:
    • Methysergide
    • Beta-adrenergic blockers
    • Lysergic acid diethylamide
    • Methyldopa
    • Amphetamines
    • Phenacetin
    • Pergolide
    • Cocaine

Explanation of Other Options:

Bendrofluazide (Option A): Thiazide group of diuretic, not associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Diltiazem (Option C): Calcium channel inhibitor, not associated with retroperitoneal fibrosis.

Aspirin (Option D): NSAIDs can cause interstitial nephritis, not retroperitoneal fibrosis.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man with high-grade non-Hodgkin lymphoma develops oliguria (250 mL/24 h) the day after completing chemotherapy. He was treated for Gram-negative sepsis with gentamicin and ceftazidime. Labs show creatinine 2.0 mg/dL, calcium 7 mg/dL, phosphate 8.3 mg/dL, uric acid 9 mg/dL. Urine shows reddish-brown, rosette-like crystals. What is the most likely cause of his oliguria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient developed acute kidney injury with oliguria shortly after chemotherapy for high-grade lymphoma, a classic setting for tumour lysis syndrome. The presence of hyperuricemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and urate crystals in urine confirms TLS as the cause of renal tubule obstruction and dysfunction.

Tumour Lysis Syndrome:

  • Typically occurs after chemotherapy for lymphoma with a large tumour burden or high-grade lymphomas.
  • TLS is most often associated with the treatment of Burkitt’s lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, and other rapidly proliferating lymphomas, but it also may be seen with chronic leukaemias and, rarely, with solid tumours.
  • Virtually all affected patients are oliguric, with an acidic urine containing numerous uric acid crystals.

Laboratory findings:

  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypocalcemia

Diagnostic Criteria (Cairo-Bishop)

TLS is diagnosed if 2 or more of the following metabolic abnormalities occur within 3 days before or 7 days after chemotherapy:

  • Uric acid ≥ 8 mg/dL
  • Potassium ≥ 6 mmol/L
  • Phosphate ≥ 4.5 mg/dL
  • Calcium ≤ 7 mg/dL

Prevention and treatment:

  • Allopurinol and aggressive hydration.
  • Febuxostat, a potent nonpurine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is indicated for the treatment of hyperuricemia.
  • Rasburicase, used when renal failure is present.
  • Despite aggressive prophylaxis, TLS and/or oliguric or anuric renal failure may occur. Dialysis is often necessary and should be considered early in the course.

Explanation of Other Options:

Ceftazidime-induced interstitial nephritis (Option A) would present with eosinophils in urine, fever, rash, but not typically with uric acid crystals or these electrolyte abnormalities.

Gentamicin nephrotoxicity (Option B) causes non-oliguric AKI; typically has granular casts, not uric acid crystals. Also develops more gradually over several days of treatment, not acutely post-chemotherapy.

Lymphomatous infiltration of the kidney (Option C): Lymphomatous infiltration of the kidney is a chronic process.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman returns from Korea with fever, myalgia, shock (BP 78/50 mmHg), cyanosis, conjunctival hemorrhage, epistaxis, and hemoptysis. She remains oliguric (5 mL/hour) despite fluids. Labs show creatinine 4.6 mg/dL, urea 182 mg/dL, Hb 9.1 g/dL, platelets 34 x 109;/L, and PT 32 seconds. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with acute renal failure, hemorrhagic features, thrombocytopenia, and a travel history to Korea, where Hantavirus (Hemorrhagic Fever with Renal Syndrome) is endemic, making it the most likely diagnosis.

Hantavirus:

  • Hantavirus causes a condition known as Haemorrhagic Fever with Renal Syndrome (HFRS).
  • HFRS is a zoonotic viral illness caused by various species of Hantavirus.
  • Transmission occurs via rodents, especially through:
    • Inhalation of aerosolized rodent excreta (urine, droppings, saliva)
  • Clinical features include:
    • Fever
    • Hemorrhagic manifestations (e.g., conjunctival hemorrhage, epistaxis)
    • Hypotension
    • Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

Lab findings:

  • Thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis
  • Mildly elevated AST, ALT
  • Elevated creatinine & urea
  • ↑ PT, aPTT, low fibrinogen (DIC)
  • Proteinuria, hematuria

Treatment:

  • Supportive care is key
    • IV fluids (careful due to capillary leak)
    • Correct electrolyte imbalance
    • Dialysis for severe AKI
  • Ribavirin (IV or oral) may reduce mortality if started early in Hantaan virus infections
  • Manage complications: DIC, ARDS, shock

Explanation of Other Options:

Wegener's granulomatosis(Option A): This involves nasal crusting, chronic upper respiratory symptoms, and C-ANCA positivity. No travel or infectious context.

Hemolytic-uraemic syndrome (Option B): It occurs after E. coli (O157:H7) infection, is more common in children, and usually has no bleeding, like epistaxis or hemoptysis.

Leptospirosis (Option C): Patient presents with jaundice, myalgia (esp. calf), conjunctival suffusion, but lacks the severe hemorrhagic features and oliguria seen in Hantavirus.

choices.text: Pre-renal failure due to a prolonged period of unconsciousness
Renal artery embolus secondary to drug injecting

questions.text: A 20-year-old registered drug addict is brought unconscious to the emergency department. It's not known how long he was on the floor of his apartment. Blood tests on admission revealed a bicarbonate of 19 mmol/l, creatinine of 2.80 mg/dl, urinary sodium of 60 mmol/l, and a urine osmolality of 220 mOsmol/l. There is evidence of acute sepsis. What diagnosis fits best with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with acute kidney injury in the setting of prolonged immobilization and sepsis, suggesting intrinsic renal damage. The high urinary sodium (60 mmol/L) and low urine osmolality (220 mOsm/kg) indicate poor tubular reabsorption and concentration, consistent with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) rather than pre-renal or vascular causes. ;

Explanation of Other Options:

Pre-renal failure due to a prolonged period of unconsciousness (Option A): Would have low urinary Na (<20) and high urine osmolality (>500)

Sepsis-induced AKI(Option B): Sepsis initially leads to reduced GFR by vasodilation, mimicking pre-renal AKI. Later in its course, sepsis leads to endothelial damage and will show features of intrinsic renal failure.

Renal artery embolus secondary to drug injection (Option D): Renal artery embolism, as in infective endocarditis, produces a glomerulonephritis-like picture with hematuria and RBC casts, which is not mentioned.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and a creatinine level of 1.85 mg/dl presents to radiology for a contrast angiography. He has had a mild episode of gastroenteritis but is keen to go ahead with the investigation. He is discharged the following morning but presents to the ER 48 hours later feeling acutely unwell. His serum creatinine level is now 2.85 mg/dl. What diagnosis fits best with this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This elderly diabetic patient with pre-existing renal impairment developed an acute rise in creatinine 48 hours after contrast exposure, which is characteristic of contrast-induced nephropathy.

Contrast-Induced Nephropathy (CIN):

  • Mechanisms of Injury:
    • Hypoxia in the renal outer medulla due to:
      • Altered renal microcirculation
      • Occlusion of small vessels
    • Cytotoxic tubular injury:
      • Direct toxicity or via oxygen free radical generation
      • Worsened by a high concentration of contrast in the tubules
    • Transient tubular obstruction from precipitated contrast material
  • Clinical Course:
    • Serum creatinine rises within 24-48 hours post-exposure
    • Peaks within 3-5 days
    • Resolves typically within 1 week
    • Severe renal impairment requiring dialysis usually occurs in patients with:
      • Advanced pre-existing renal failure
      • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Risk Factors for CIN:
    • Diabetic nephropathy
    • Coexistent hypovolemia
    • Multiple myeloma
    • Pre-existing chronic kidney disease (CKD)
  • Laboratory Findings:
    • Low fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa)
    • Benign urinary sediment
    • Usually no features of tubular necrosis
  • Prevention Strategies:
    • Prehydration with normal saline
    • N-acetylcysteine may reduce the risk
    • Avoid volume overload during fluid administration

Explanation of Other Options:

Worsening diabetic nephropathy (Option A): Typically causes slow, chronic progression, not an acute 1-day spike.

Haemolytic-uraemic syndrome (HUS) (Option B): Associated with microangiopathy, anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and bloody diarrhoea

Renal artery occlusion (Option D): Would cause sudden, severe pain and acute anuria, not this picture.

questions.text: Fractional Excretion <1% occurs in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The FeNa is the fraction of the filtered sodium load that is not reabsorbed by the tubules, and is a measure of both the kidney’s ability to reabsorb sodium as well as endogenously and exogenously administered factors that affect tubular reabsorption.
  • With prerenal azotemia, the FeNa may be <1%, suggesting avid tubular sodium reabsorption.
  • In patients with CKD, a FeNa significantly >1% can be present despite a superimposed prerenal state.
  • Most common conditions associated with prerenal azotemia: Hypovolemia, decreased cardiac output, and medications that interfere with renal autoregulatory vascular response, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and inhibitors of angiotensin II.
  • In the context of a decreased GFR, autoregulatory mechanisms lead to prostacyclin-mediated dilation of the afferent arteriole and ACE-mediated efferent arteriolar vasoconstriction.
  • NSAIDS cause inhibition of afferent arteriolar vasodilation and a decrease in GFR.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acute tubulointerstitial nephritis (Option A): Results in FeNa >1% due to tubular inflammation impairing sodium reabsorption.

Ischemia AKI (Option B): Typically results in FeNa >1% due to tubular injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are novel biomarkers for acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kidney injury molecule-1 (KIM-1) and neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL) are well-established biomarkers for AKI, detectable in urine and plasma soon after injury.

  • Kidney injury molecule-1 (KIM-1) is a type 1 transmembrane protein that is abundantly expressed in proximal tubular cells injured by ischemia or multiple, distinct nephrotoxins, such as cisplatin. It can be detected after ischemic or nephrotoxic injury in the urine and plasma.
  • Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL, also known as lipocalin-2 or siderocalin) is another biomarker of AKI. NGAL was first discovered as a protein in granules of human neutrophils. It is highly upregulated after inflammation and kidney injury and can be detected in the plasma and urine within 2 hr of cardiopulmonary bypass-associated AKI.

Other biomarkers include:

  • Plasma levels of soluble urokinase Plasminogen Activator Receptor (suPAR)
  • Tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase-2 (TIMP-2) and insulin-like growth factor binding protein 7 (IGFBP7) are cell-cycle arrest biomarkers used together to predict the risk of moderate to severe AKI in critically ill patients. They are not standalone diagnostic markers but are valuable for early risk stratification. (Option C ruled out)
  • Cystatin C
  • Osteopontin
  • β-D-glucosaminidase
  • Clusterin

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of acute renal failure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypernatremia is not a typical complication of acute renal failure.

Complications of AKI:

  1. Hypervolemia: due to impaired salt water excretion; Hypovolemiamay occur during the polyuric phase of recovery, which is heralded by an increase in urine output (Option B ruled out)
  2. Hyponatremia
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Metabolic acidosis
  5. Hyperphosphatemia
  6. Hypocalcemia
  7. Infections (Both precipitant and complications of AKI) (Option A ruled out)
  8. Cardiac complications: arrhythmias, pericarditis, and pericardial effusion. (Option D ruled out)
  9. Malnutrition (due to Hypercatabolic state)
  10. Uremia

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is most likely to cause postoperative Acute Kidney Injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The procedures most commonly associated with AKI are cardiac surgery withcardiopulmonary bypass(particularly for combined valve and bypass procedures), vascular procedures with aortic cross-clamping, and intraperitoneal
  • Severe AKI requiring dialysis occurs in ~1% of cardiac and vascular surgery procedures.
  • Longer durationof cardiopulmonary bypass is a risk factor for AKI.

Mechanisms of AKI in Cardiopulmonary Bypass Procedures:

  • Ischemic injury from sustained hypoperfusion
  • Extracorporeal circuit activation of leukocytes and inflammatory processes
  • Hemolysis with resultant pigment nephropathy
  • Aortic injury with resultant atheroemboli.

Explanation of Other Options:

Thyroidectomy (Option A): Unlikely to affect the kidneys unless there is massive bleeding or rare complications.

Decompressive Hemicraniectomy (Option B): Brain surgery not directly associated with AKI unless complicated by prolonged hypotension or sepsis.

Umbilical Hernia Repair (Option C): Minor abdominal surgery with minimal risk of postoperative AKI.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements as per definition of Acute Kidney Injury according to KDIGO?
i. Rise in s. creatinine from baseline of ≥ 0.3 mg/dl within 1 week
ii. Rise in s. creatinine from baseline of ≥ 50% within 1 week
iii. Reduction in urine output to <0.5ml/kg/hour for ≥ 6 hours
questions.solution:
Explanation:

AKI is currently defined by a:

  • Rise from baseline of ≥0.3 mg/dL within 48 h OR
  • ≥ 50% higher than baseline within 1 week OR
  • A reduction in urine output to <0.5 mL/kg per h for longer than 6 h

KDIGO staging of AKI:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cause renal impairment by causing interstitial nephritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Quinolones can cause renal impairment through interstitial nephritis.

Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) is classically caused by:

  • Antibiotics: β-lactams, sulfonamides, rifampicin, quinolones
  • NSAIDs
  • Diuretics (especially thiazides)
  • PPIs

Mechanism of Renal Impairment by Quinolones:

Quinolones cause renal impairment by acting as haptens, triggering a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction leading to acute interstitial nephritis (AIN). This results in interstitial inflammation and edema, impairing tubular function, causing electrolyte wasting, low urine osmolality, and non-oliguric AKI with pyuria, eosinophiluria, and mild proteinuria.

Drugs causing acute tubular necrosis:

  • Vancomycin causes intratubular obstruction (Option B ruled out)
  • Aminoglycosides, Hypomagnesemia is also seen with Aminoglycosides (Option A ruled out)
  • Amphotericin B causes distal RTA with hypomagnesemia and hypocalcemia. (Option C ruled out)
  • Acyclovir causes intratubular obstruction
  • Foscarnet
  • Tenofovir
  • Cidofovir

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cause proximal RTA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ifosfamide causes proximal RTA.

Renal Tubular Acidosis:

Renal Tubular Acidosis is a group of disorders in which the kidneys fail to acidify urine properly, leading to normal anion gap metabolic acidosis despite preserved glomerular filtration rate.

questions.text: A low anion gap is seen in all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The anion gap is calculated with the formula (Na + K) - (Cl + HCO3).
  • Normally, there is an anion excess in our body. Anion gap signifies the unmeasured anions in the plasma, which include albumin, phosphate, sulfate, and organic anions.
  • Anion gap = Unmeasured anions - unmeasured cations
  • Normal AG ≈ 8 - 12 mEq/L

A decrease in the AG can be due to:

  • An increase in unmeasured cations
  • The addition to the blood of abnormal cations, such as lithium (lithium intoxication) or cationic immunoglobulins. (plasma cell dyscrasias)
  • A reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration (nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or malabsorption)
  • Hyperviscosity and severe hyperlipidemia can lead to an underestimation of sodium and chloride concentrations.
